summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel and an FBI Special Agent regarding the preparation and delivery of "Maxwell 3500 Materials," specifically interview notes and FBI 302 reports, for an upcoming legal deadline in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The emails discuss the format and logistics of transferring these investigative documents.

persons.name: Andrew Rohrbach
persons.context: He is the primary sender of the initial request for all interview notes and 302s related to the Maxwell case, copying others to coordinate logistics.

persons.name: Phifer
persons.context: Copied on an email asking about the format of the Maxwell 3500 materials, indicating involvement in the document preparation process.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: Copied on the initial request for Maxwell 3500 materials, suggesting her involvement in the case preparation and logistics.

persons.name: Lara Pomerantz
persons.context: Copied on the initial request for Maxwell 3500 materials, indicating her role in the legal team preparing for the Maxwell case deadline.

connections.description: Both are Assistant U.S. Attorneys copied on the same email chain coordinating the collection of Maxwell case materials.
Both are Assistant U.S. Attorneys copied on the same email chain coordinating the collection of Maxwell case materials.
Rohrbach's request is forwarded to Phifer, a contractor, who inquires about the document format, showing a working relationship in document preparation.

events.title: Preparation for Maxwell 3500 Deadline
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office is urgently preparing to meet a "3500 deadline," requesting a complete set of interview notes and FBI 302 reports from the entire Maxwell case dating back to 2019.

keyFacts: The document is an email chain concerning the urgent preparation of "Maxwell 3500 Materials" for an upcoming legal deadline.
The requested materials include a complete set of interview notes and FBI 302 reports from the entire Ghislaine Maxwell case back to 2019.
The correspondence involves multiple Assistant U.S. Attorneys and a contractor, indicating coordinated effort within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
The emails discuss the logistical details of obtaining these documents, specifically noting they will be delivered in a serial-numbered format, not by report title.
